trans-unit.source: Understand planned vs. unplanned maintenance
trans-unit.target: Understand planned vs. unplanned maintenance

trans-unit.source: There are two types of Microsoft Azure platform events that can affect the availability of your virtual machines: planned maintenance and unplanned maintenance.
trans-unit.target: There are two types of Microsoft Azure platform events that can affect the availability of your virtual machines: planned maintenance and unplanned maintenance.

trans-unit.source: **Planned maintenance events** are periodic updates made by Microsoft to the underlying Azure platform to improve overall reliability, performance, and security of the platform infrastructure that your virtual machines run on.
trans-unit.target: **Planned maintenance events** are periodic updates made by Microsoft to the underlying Azure platform to improve overall reliability, performance, and security of the platform infrastructure that your virtual machines run on.

trans-unit.source: The majority of these updates are performed without any impact upon your virtual machines or cloud services.
trans-unit.target: The majority of these updates are performed without any impact upon your virtual machines or cloud services.

trans-unit.source: However, there are instances where these updates require a reboot of your virtual machine to apply the required updates to the platform infrastructure.
trans-unit.target: However, there are instances where these updates require a reboot of your virtual machine to apply the required updates to the platform infrastructure.

trans-unit.source: **Unplanned maintenance events** occur when the hardware or physical infrastructure underlying your virtual machine has faulted in some way.
trans-unit.target: **Unplanned maintenance events** occur when the hardware or physical infrastructure underlying your virtual machine has faulted in some way.

trans-unit.source: This may include local network failures, local disk failures, or other rack level failures.
trans-unit.target: This may include local network failures, local disk failures, or other rack level failures.

trans-unit.source: When such a failure is detected, the Azure platform will automatically migrate your virtual machine from the unhealthy physical machine hosting your virtual machine to a healthy physical machine.
trans-unit.target: When such a failure is detected, the Azure platform will automatically migrate your virtual machine from the unhealthy physical machine hosting your virtual machine to a healthy physical machine.

trans-unit.source: Such events are rare, but may also cause your virtual machine to reboot.
trans-unit.target: Such events are rare, but may also cause your virtual machine to reboot.

trans-unit.source: Configure multiple virtual machines in an Availability Set for redundancy
trans-unit.target: Configure multiple virtual machines in an Availability Set for redundancy

trans-unit.source: To provide redundancy to your application, we recommend that you group two or more virtual machines in an Availability Set.
trans-unit.target: To provide redundancy to your application, we recommend that you group two or more virtual machines in an Availability Set.

trans-unit.source: This configuration ensures that during either a planned or unplanned maintenance event, at least one virtual machine will be available and meet the 99.95% Azure SLA.
trans-unit.target: This configuration ensures that during either a planned or unplanned maintenance event, at least one virtual machine will be available and meet the 99.95% Azure SLA.

trans-unit.source: For more information about service level agreements, see the “Cloud Services, virtual machines, and Virtual Network” section in [Service Level Agreements](../../../support/legal/sla/).
trans-unit.target: For more information about service level agreements, see the “Cloud Services, virtual machines, and Virtual Network” section in [Service Level Agreements](../../../support/legal/sla/).

trans-unit.source: Each virtual machine in your Availability Set is assigned an Update Domain (UD) and a Fault Domain (FD) by the underlying Azure platform.
trans-unit.target: Each virtual machine in your Availability Set is assigned an Update Domain (UD) and a Fault Domain (FD) by the underlying Azure platform.

trans-unit.source: For a given Availability Set, five non-user-configurable UDs are assigned to indicate groups of virtual machines and underlying physical hardware that can be rebooted at the same time.
trans-unit.target: For a given Availability Set, five non-user-configurable UDs are assigned to indicate groups of virtual machines and underlying physical hardware that can be rebooted at the same time.

trans-unit.source: When more than five virtual machines are configured within a single Availability Set, the sixth virtual machine will be placed into the same UD as the first virtual machine, the seventh in the same UD as the second virtual machine, and so on.
trans-unit.target: When more than five virtual machines are configured within a single Availability Set, the sixth virtual machine will be placed into the same UD as the first virtual machine, the seventh in the same UD as the second virtual machine, and so on.

trans-unit.source: The order of UDs being rebooted may not proceed sequentially during planned maintenance, but only one UD will be rebooted at a time.
trans-unit.target: The order of UDs being rebooted may not proceed sequentially during planned maintenance, but only one UD will be rebooted at a time.

trans-unit.source: FDs define the group of virtual machines that share a common power source and network switch.
trans-unit.target: FDs define the group of virtual machines that share a common power source and network switch.

trans-unit.source: By default, the virtual machines configured within your Availability Set are separated across two FDs.
trans-unit.target: By default, the virtual machines configured within your Availability Set are separated across two FDs.

trans-unit.source: While placing your virtual machines into an Availability Set does not protect your application from operating system or application-specific failures, it does limit the impact of potential physical hardware failures, network outages, or power interruptions.
trans-unit.target: While placing your virtual machines into an Availability Set does not protect your application from operating system or application-specific failures, it does limit the impact of potential physical hardware failures, network outages, or power interruptions.

trans-unit.source: Configure each application tier into separate Availability Sets If the virtual machines in your Availability Set are all nearly identical and serve the same purpose for your application, we recommend that you configure an Availability Set for each tier of your application.
trans-unit.target: Configure each application tier into separate Availability Sets If the virtual machines in your Availability Set are all nearly identical and serve the same purpose for your application, we recommend that you configure an Availability Set for each tier of your application.

trans-unit.source: If you place two different tiers in the same Availability Set, all virtual machines in the same application tier can be rebooted at once.
trans-unit.target: If you place two different tiers in the same Availability Set, all virtual machines in the same application tier can be rebooted at once.

trans-unit.source: By configuring at least two virtual machines in an Availability Set for each tier, you guarantee that at least one virtual machine in each tier will be available.
trans-unit.target: By configuring at least two virtual machines in an Availability Set for each tier, you guarantee that at least one virtual machine in each tier will be available.

trans-unit.source: For example, you could put all the virtual machines in the front-end of your application running IIS, Apache, Nginx, etc., in a single Availability Set.
trans-unit.target: For example, you could put all the virtual machines in the front-end of your application running IIS, Apache, Nginx, etc., in a single Availability Set.

trans-unit.source: Make sure that only front-end virtual machines are placed in the same Availability Set.
trans-unit.target: Make sure that only front-end virtual machines are placed in the same Availability Set.

trans-unit.source: Similarly, make sure that only data-tier virtual machines are placed in their own Availability Set, like your replicated SQL Server virtual machines or your MySQL virtual machines.
trans-unit.target: Similarly, make sure that only data-tier virtual machines are placed in their own Availability Set, like your replicated SQL Server virtual machines or your MySQL virtual machines.

trans-unit.source: Combine the Load Balancer with Availability Sets
trans-unit.target: Combine the Load Balancer with Availability Sets

trans-unit.source: Combine the Azure Load Balancer with an Availability Set to get the most application resiliency.
trans-unit.target: Combine the Azure Load Balancer with an Availability Set to get the most application resiliency.

trans-unit.source: The Azure Load Balancer distributes traffic between multiple virtual machines.
trans-unit.target: The Azure Load Balancer distributes traffic between multiple virtual machines.

trans-unit.source: For our Standard tier virtual machines, the Azure Load Balancer is included.
trans-unit.target: For our Standard tier virtual machines, the Azure Load Balancer is included.

trans-unit.source: Note that not all virtual machine tiers include the Azure Load Balancer.
trans-unit.target: Note that not all virtual machine tiers include the Azure Load Balancer.

trans-unit.source: For more information about load balancing your virtual machines, read [Load Balancing virtual machines](../load-balance-virtual-machines.md).
trans-unit.target: For more information about load balancing your virtual machines, read [Load Balancing virtual machines](../load-balance-virtual-machines.md).

trans-unit.source: If the load balancer is not configured to balance traffic across multiple virtual machines, then any planned maintenance event will affect the only traffic-serving virtual machine, causing an outage to your application tier.
trans-unit.target: If the load balancer is not configured to balance traffic across multiple virtual machines, then any planned maintenance event will affect the only traffic-serving virtual machine, causing an outage to your application tier.

trans-unit.source: Placing multiple virtual machines of the same tier under the same load balancer and Availability Set enables traffic to be continuously served by at least one instance.
trans-unit.target: Placing multiple virtual machines of the same tier under the same load balancer and Availability Set enables traffic to be continuously served by at least one instance.

trans-unit.source: Avoid single instance virtual machines in Availability Sets
trans-unit.target: Avoid single instance virtual machines in Availability Sets

trans-unit.source: Avoid leaving a single instance virtual machine in an Availability Set by itself.
trans-unit.target: Avoid leaving a single instance virtual machine in an Availability Set by itself.

trans-unit.source: Virtual machines in this configuration do not qualify for a SLA guarantee and will face downtime during Azure planned maintenance events.
trans-unit.target: Virtual machines in this configuration do not qualify for a SLA guarantee and will face downtime during Azure planned maintenance events.

trans-unit.source: Please note, single virtual machine instance within an Availability Set, will also receive advanced email notification in multi-instance virtual machines planned maintenance notification.
trans-unit.target: Please note, single virtual machine instance within an Availability Set, will also receive advanced email notification in multi-instance virtual machines planned maintenance notification.
